You know what would be an interesting story if they want to do a black mermaid but have it connected to The Little Mermaid? A mermaid living off the shores of Africa that hears a strange story of another mermaid from another part of the world that got legs. Since the story was passed by word of fish, it's a little mucked up and overly fantastical by the time she hears it. But armed with the knowledge that maybe she could get legs too, as she has dreamed of for her own reasons, and explore the world of humans she would go on an adventure of figuring out how to do that. She would find her own way of getting legs and satisfy her curiosity of humanity. Or, upon learning how Ariel got her legs she decides against it and does something else. Idk, there's a lot of potential that COULD have been looked into for a unique story.

Cultural appropriation
The little mermaid is based on the Danish author Hans Christian Andersens book Den lille havfrue and the illustration to the book was made by Edmund Dulac. It was published in 1837 . 
In the original book it say" den yngste var den smukkeste af dem allesammans, hendes hud var saa klar og skjær som et rosenblad, bendes øine saa blåa, som den dybeste sø,
(the youngest was the most beautiful one, her skin was so fair and soft like a rose petal, her eyes as blue as the deepest sea.) Another part from original book : never imagined that a pretty little mermaid was standing beneath them, holding out her White hands towards the keel of their ship

There is even a statue of the little mermaid in Denmark standing in the capital, Copenhagen at the harbor commission in 1909. This statue is so culturally significant to the Danish people and rooted deep in the culture, that for the EXPO in 2010 it was decided to relocate " the little mermaid". The statue was relocated to Shanghai to be placed in the Denmark pavilion at the EXPO, it was a huge expense to do it, but they wanted to show their cultural heritage.

To make it short. The little mermaid is both historically and culturally significant character for Denamrk, with a very long history and has been seen all over the world. Because of the history behind the story my prediction for this movie will be bad in most of Europe, but far worse in the Scandinavian countries.

The skin color of the actress is not the issue, it is Disney Americanization of European culture that is being pushed at the Europeans, this is why Euro Disney wasn't liked in Europe but really despised when it opened. Euro Disney was rebranded and huge cultural changes of the park operation and designs to not offend the Europeans.

Before you all get your panties in a twist and say the movie is not the same, Disney did acknowledge the statue and the culture of Denmark by adding the pose of the statue in the movie. Add to it, the script from 1930 that Disney did but also the notes and changes by H.C Andersen. Not to mention right before the exit of the little mermaid ride at Disney California Adventure Park, be on the lookout for a tribute to the Little Mermaid’s original author, Hans Christian Andersen but also Copenhagen's famous Little Mermaid Statue ( Den Lille Havfrue)

This is very American - centric to ignore the deep cultural and historical affection ingrained in European cultures and how this characters are important to Europeans and especially to the Danes.

You say The Little Mermaid is just a story would be like saying, the Mona Lisa is just a painting or the Coliseum is just a building. They are not just a story, just a painting or just a building. They are deeply tied to the culture and people. Everyone in Europe know that the Little Mermaid is deeply tied to the culture and people of Denmark. 
By inserting American - centric culture war ideology onto the screen is a huge mistake by Disney.

Replica of the little mermaid statue
Solvang California, installed by Earl and Dolores Peterson in 1976, This is America's biggest danish settlement and has a substantial tourist industry based on its Danish heritage. It was founded in 1911

Navy HQ in Brazil, was donated to Brazil 1960, the sign reads. "The little mermaid" donated to Brazil by friends in Denmark. In admiration of the Brazilian Initiative recalling the traditional courtesy of the Brazilian navy to the little mermaid in Copenhagen under the auspices of the Royal Danish Government Society of the friends of Brazil in Denmark. Danish - Brazilian company with the participation of the following friends

Window of the world, Shenzhen China ,

Carlsberg breweries, Denmark, made by Paul Lauritz Rasmussen 1937
Tivoli, Denmark, a replica was made and placed in Tivoli 2010 while the original was on a trip to China EXPO. The statue in Tivoli garden is reduced to as the little sister of the little mermaid. When the original statue returned to it rightfully place in the harbor the little sister was returned to its owners.

Yokohama, Japan, the statue is placed on the corner of the building that houses the Scandia Restaurant. A small section of the corner of the building was carved out to make room for the statue.

Pietra Neemt, Romania, Mica Sirens ( the little mermaid)was donated to the city in 2000 in honor of Queen Margrethe Of Denmark visiting the city

Seoul, South Korea,installed 2016,reviled by both Danish and South Korean government officials in and effort to strengthen the relationship between the countries

Parque Europe, Madrid Spain, the park has a lavishly landscape and has 17 monuments replicas throughout Europe. Plus and original piece of the Berlin wall. So the little mermaid is only one of them

St. Thomas Charlotte Amalie, Virgin Islands, there is a substantial danish heritage and history on the island and on the sign it says: A true copy in half-size of the little mermaid created by the Danish sculpture Edvard Eriksen, erected in 1918 at Langrijke in Copenhagen, Denmark

Glendale, California,USA, placed here by actress Greer Varsin in memory of her mother, As this place is a cemetery it is a resting place of many celebrities. Errol Flynn, Michael Jackson, Elizabeth Taylor, Spencer Tracy, just to mention a few of them.

Greenwich, Connecticut, USA, grave of a famous danish - American pianist/actor/composer/comedian by the name of Victor Borge, in memory of his homeland. He arrived in America 1940 after escaping the Nazis.

Kimballton, Iowa, USA, if was first made of fiberglass and put in place 1978, due to major water damages it was recasted in bronze 2008 and replaced the damaged statue. The inscription on the fountain reads: H.C Andersen fairytale " The little Mermaid" the story of a mermaid longing for the love of a mortal prince and for and immortal human soul.

Greenville, Michigan, USA, in 2009, 15 years after the sculpture was made there was a huge law sue of copyrights that was later dropped. The inscription by the statue reads: In one of Hans Christian Andersen's best known fairytale, a mermaid has to choose between her love for a prince and life under the sea. This replica of Edvard Eriksen statue that grace the harbor in Copenhagen, Denmark was crafted by artist Steven Williston and dedicated on August 18, 1994, by the Danish Festival Board in honor of this area's proud danish heritage.

International Peace Garden, Salt Lake City, Utan, USA, was the third place to receive permission by the Danish King and the artist, Er are Eriksen, to have a copy of the famous mermaid statue, which was placed there on June 5th, 1955 (Danish constitution day)

The cartoon Little Mermaid strays wildly from the original Hans Christien Andersen tale, the characters are American – made by Disney – and there's no mention of Danish culture... But suddenly the same story is told with an actress of colour as the lead and now suddenly it's 'hijacked'? There are videos circulating of little girls and boys of colour delighted to see an Ariel who looks like them - that's the power of this choice. There are also people of colour in Denmark... so the idea of being 'Danish' and necessarily white doesn't stand up in this day and age. We are also talking about a MERMAID - an actual creature of fantasy! If you can suspend your disbelief enough to conceive of a mythical white mermaid, a mermaid of colour really shouldn't be a huge leap and worthy of making a video like this... Very telling that you, as a white (presumably heterosexual) man are making this video because you've never had to live your life without seeing yourself represented. The truth is, if you're looking for authenticity, go and read the original tale, even better if you can do so in Danish... This is a modern film made for modern audiences, and maybe, just maybe, it's a blockbuster that for once wasn't made to cater to people with privilege (not that anyone with privilege is unable to watch and enjoy this film because the lead is a person of colour!) If being 'woke' means giving a voice and a platform to those who are continually marginalised, I'm all for it. And, yes, I agree that it would be amazing to see Disney films that tell stories of more people and cultures across the world (but the actress is also American, and there are plenty of people of colour in America and Europe), and in all likelihood, you wouldn't have made a video saying so if the lead in this remake had been white...

I find it so ironic that certain people have a problem with recasting fictional characters in shows and movies when certain people have been performing cultural appropriation for years. This is not the first time that Disney have recasted a cartoon for a live action movie. They made a multiracial version of Cinderella with the singers Brandy and Whitney Houston. There was a issue with that too. There was a issue about Disney having a princess of color too.

Let me tell you what the real problem is. There is no. Woke agenda going on. It just some folks are highly upset that their favorite childhood cartoon character was replaced by a brown face character. Let me just educate some people of mermaid folklore on a global scale. There are folklores pertaining to mermaids of all colors on every continent. Folklores in Europe, Asia, Africa, North America and Central and South America. In Africa, mermaids are called Mami Wata and are considered to be Water spirits. So, Disney just brought out cultural representation of another version of the Little Mermaid.

People just need to stop with their fake outrage about why they don’t like this trailer and be really honest about how they feel about certain things instead of making up fake conspiracy theories. People of color had to deal with cultural appropriation since the entertainment industry was established. We had to deal with racism in entertainment.. All that people have to do is to go back and rewatch the older Disney cartoons and others to see how cartoonists depicted people of color and kids of color had no characters to really identify with historically in cartoons. Now little Black girls and others can identify with princesses who look like them and people of all races should celebrate this moment for their kids to see the beauty of all people regardless of culture or race. . What is wrong with that? Non-Disney related, does anyone remember the old cartoon Betty Boop? In the cartoon, she was depicted as a Caucasian character. However, that cartoonist modeled the character after Black entertainer named Esther Jones

But people want to get pissed off just because people of color finally have their opportunity to have representation in entertainment. People are actually mad over a cartoon character that is fictional by the way because of her skin color and they have the ultimate audacity to say they’re not angry because of that. That’s a bold faced lie They’re mad because they don’t like to see change…it scares them with horror. We will always have the original but this updated version can be enjoyed by everyone

I'll be the first to admit that there is so much shoehorning of race and diversity in the media and advertising today, that it is actually painful. Going to a store these days and seeing everyone but a white individual in the signage is lazy virtue signaling, and it detracts from the supposed message of inclusion by first excluding (ironic obviously), but secondly just making it look insincere. Add the excessive irruption of race issues in unnatural environments, just to force the conversation, are you do have genuine objections. But this film IS the wrong battle, and to have a problem with it is in fact proving there is a point to the idea that it's just blind reactionism. The Little Mermaid is a FANTASY, as it has been sagaciously pointed out, and nowhere in the lores of yore does it say the mermaid has to look a certain way. Yes, we all know that Disney is doing this now to promote the Zeitgeist du Jour (anyone love my Franco-German juxtapose?), but as long as the story checks out, so what? So I'm not on board on this one, and people should have refrained from downvoting until AFTER watching the film, which may give them enough reasons to downvote in the end, but NOT before. Otherwise, it does appear like blind reactionism.

The original story matters. It's not simply a "fairytale". The story is based on European folklore and mythology. Andersen confirmed and admitted to this himself.

Virtually any malevolent movement throughout history has sought to eradicate or replace a people's culture in order to destroy them. It robs people of their sense of self. When you race swap a cultural work like this it is both disrespectful and harmful to the culture whose folklore/mythology it is.

One of the first stories I read in this genre as a child was a Caldecott award winning book about Anansi who is an African trickster god in a similar vein to Loki. Nobody would cast a white actor as Anansi. It's the same exact thing here. People need to stop grasping for straws. You are being disrespectful of a culture at best and an absolute racist and bigot at worst by taking pleasure in a race swap of a cultural work like this.

4:34 - The article mentions Disney's "color-blind casting". It's not color-blind to specifically look for someone who ISN'T white. To be color-blind means you audition everyone who applies regardless of skin color (black, white, indian, latino, asian, pacific islander, etc.) and hire the best actor/actress. It's different, of course, if the ethnicity of the person is relevant to the story. Not a lot of non-blacks live in Wakanda so expect to see a very monotone skin color for the residents there. And that's ok. It's not ok to take an existing character (Ariel & the Blue Fairy among them) and to NOT look for someone who meets their existing characteristics, to in fact look for someone who is purposefully different. If you're writing an original character and their race isn't relevant to the story audition everyone and hire the one who gives the best performance, not the one with the most woke credentials. Race should only be considered if it's important to the story (which includes matching existing canon ethnicity)(and sexuality, but I don't want to get into THAT discussion right now)

So, I had posted (below) this to another YouTube channel discussing this very issue... I'll share my thoughts on this here.

"This is the problem; it is not that Disney cannot make a successful movie; it is that Disney has lost its way in making new, original movies to highlight rising black women in the arts of acting. As for Halle Bailey being a lead actor in a Disney movie, I am absolutely sure she would have made a great original character [such as Tiana in 'Princess and the Frog].

However, Disney has lost it way in using Halle to portray her as 'Ariel' in Little Mermaid; this will not be a successful movie just for this one fact [alone]. However, if Disney had any interest in creating a role and character around Halle to gain wide-spread acceptance, they should have done so [to the credit of all fans].

Disney could have simply used Halle in a movie role of The Princess and Frog. This would have been a far better choice and a more likely successful role for Halle and Disney. But why Disney chose 'Little Mermaid' is questionable, and it most certainly causes unnecessary discontent and disappointment to fans with Disney as a whole... at least in my opinion.

If Disney's leaders think by causing controversy for political/social gains is their new model, it (so far) has shown time and time again that it does not work. Perhaps Disney's leaders like the hemorrhaging of economic collapse for tampering with old success. I for one think it is troubling and unnecessary."

Why Disney continues to do this is ridiculous; it is an insult to the characters they've made over the decades... you cannot justify changing the identity of a well-established character just because it is the 'woke' thing to do. But for Disney not trying to be original at all, it just destroys all that Disney once was and what it could be... Walt would be rolling in his grave. We'd surely would not accept to change the identity of Tiana to become a white trans (male) Princess no more than we would accept Disney to change the identity of Mickey toward becoming a purple elephant -- Tiana is a Black Female and Mickey is a Black & White male mouse... this is well established. If, however, Disney wants to create a White Trans (male) into a Princess, then so be it, but create an original character to play the part. The same for a purple elephant. This too goes for Marvel and DC comic characters; don't change the identity of already existing Heros, just create new ones to play the 'woke' parts.
